1991.definition: Felony conviction is prohibitive for firearm purchase/possession
State dealer license required for handgun sales
Record keeping and retention required for licensed dealers for handgun sales
Reporting of sales records to the state required for licensed dealers for handgun sales
State is not required to purge sales records for at least 60 days after purchase
Purchase of handguns from licensed dealers and private sellers restricted to age 21 and older
Permit required to carry concealed weapons
Authorities are required to revoke concealed carry permits under certain circumstances

Background checks for gun sales or permits have more than a three-day limit in which they must be completed
Required background checks include an explicit requirement for search of state mental health records
State conducts separate background checks, beyond the federal NICS check, for all firearms
State conducts separate background checks, beyond the federal NICS check, for handguns
The law allows a family member or law enforcement officer to initiate a procedure to confiscate firearms from any person who is deemed by a judge to represent a threat to themselves or others
The law allows a law enforcement officer to initiate a procedure to confiscate firearms from any person who is deemed by a judge to represent a threat to themselves or others

The law allows a law enforcement officer to initiate a procedure to confiscate firearms from any person who by virtue of impaired mental health is deemed by a judge to represent a threat to themselves or others
No gun carrying on elementary school property, including concealed weapons permittees
Permit required to carry concealed weapons
Concealed carry permit process requires a background check
Authorities are required to revoke concealed carry permits under certain circumstances
No stand your ground law
State law automatically prohibits misdemeanor crime of domestic violence (MCDV) offenders from possessing firearms
MCDV convictions are prohibiting if the victim is a dating partner of the offender
State law allows law enforcement to remove firearms from MCDV offenders
State law automatically prohibits domestic violence-related restraining order (DVRO) subjects from possessing firearms
Ex parte (temporary) DVRO subjects are automatically prohibited from possessing firearms
State law requires DVRO subjects to surrender their firearms
State law requires ex parte DVRO subjects to surrender their firearms
A stalking conviction is prohibitive for firearm possession
